channel.title: Drugs. Legalization Vs Prohibiton
channel.description: In my English class we had a debate. Keeping drugs illegal, or legalizing them. I don't see any valid reason why drugs should be made legal, and how it would benefit anyone. Don't get me wrong, I smoke weed, but I don't find that any currently illegal drug should be made legal. If you have any good reasons why drugs should be made legal, please discuss.

item.title: Drugs. Legalization Vs Prohibiton
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

government conspiracy number 1

Read full topic

item.title: Drugs. Legalization Vs Prohibiton
item.dc:creator: @I_R_Craids I_R_Craids
item.description:
@I_R_Craids wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:24, topic:340183”][quote author=I_R_Craids link=topic=436552.msg3292072#msg3292072 date=1280685612]Most people whine that they want weed legalized and brag how they know it’s going to happen because the economy needs it, but at the same time they think once it’s legalized it’s going to be a free for all of mari-jane in every block, no…sorry, not in the U.S…just doesn’t work like that here.
[/quote]

The point is it shouldn’t be a free-for-all.[/quote]
I know it shouldn’t, I was just stating what most American kids who don’t know worth a crap about government think about it.
I don’t think weed should be illegal, I think it could pursue some great medical breakthroughs, but I do believe it should be kept under control by government.

Read full topic

I_R_Craids:

Most people whine that they want weed legalized and brag how they know it’s going to happen because the economy needs it, but at the same time they think once it’s legalized it’s going to be a free for all of mari-jane in every block, no…sorry, not in the U.S…just doesn’t work like that here.

The point is it shouldn’t be a free-for-all.

item.title: Drugs. Legalization Vs Prohibiton
item.dc:creator: @I_R_Craids I_R_Craids
item.description:
@I_R_Craids wrote:

pure2ownage:

They would legalize weed and ban smoking; due to it causing more deaths / year then weed. no matter what. its more dangerous; due to the excessive use of chemicals in it (2-5x weed)

Banning tobacco would be an impossibility because of the power these huge tobacco industries have.
Also, even if they do legalize weed, there is no doubt that you will need a license to sell it, and in order to grow it you’d have to have a permit which would take loads of paper work to get. Most people whine that they want weed legalized and brag how they know it’s going to happen because the economy needs it, but at the same time they think once it’s legalized it’s going to be a free for all of mari-jane in every block, no…sorry, not in the U.S…just doesn’t work like that here.

Read full topic

item.title: Drugs. Legalization Vs Prohibiton
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

RXVL:

Neither. Decriminalize, I don’t want every single store on the corner to sell packs of pre-rolled joints. Companies will do the same thing they did to tobacco.

That probably wouldn’t be a problem - at the moment illegal drugs have like the biggest markup in the world. Even taxed, they’d be cheaper.

Read full topic

item.title: Drugs. Legalization Vs Prohibiton
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

sppt:

Not sure if you’ve heard of it, but the owner of Pax, a weed boat in Breda got arrested for having weed in his car which he was gonna bring to his coffeeshop on the water. Not sure what happend afterwards though.

A few weeks ago I read a story in a newspaper about a coffeeshop owner in Groningen. We have something that is called a ‘backdoor policy’. Basically coffeeshop owners are allowed to purchase weed, but it has to be delivered through the back door. The coffeeshop in Groningen didn’t have a backdoor, so he rented a crane and had his weed delivered trough a window.

I’d say legalize though. We can tax it all we want then.

Read full topic

item.title: Drugs. Legalization Vs Prohibiton
item.dc:creator: @RXVL RXVL
item.description:
@RXVL wrote:

Neither. Decriminalize, I don’t want every single store on the corner to sell packs of pre-rolled joints. I’d rather have to grow it myself or buy it from a trusted friend and take rips from my bong all day long. Companies will do the same thing they did to tobacco. Phillip Morris (Marlboro cigarettes) already has a patent out for cigarettes blended with marijuana. I really don’t want that.

Read full topic

[quote=“Eh Pretty Easy, post:3, topic:340183”]Look at Amsterdam. Has it caused any problems there? No. More like millions of extra trourists yearly.[/quote]The Netherlands is such a bad example though. I’d take a look at Spain instead.

item.title: Drugs. Legalization Vs Prohibiton
item.dc:creator: @sppt sppt
item.description:
@sppt wrote:

R.I.P RSC:

Drugs aren’t completely legal in the Netherlands. I’m not that interested in that part of the law, but as far as I know coffeeshops are allowed to sell it, you are allowed to smoke it in designated areas, and you are allowed to grow 3 plants for personal use. I don’t think the shops are buying their drugs legally though.

Not sure if you’ve heard of it, but the owner of Pax, a weed boat in Breda got arrested for having weed in his car which he was gonna bring to his coffeeshop on the water. Not sure what happend afterwards though.

Read full topic

item.title: Drugs. Legalization Vs Prohibiton
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“Andrew, post:8, topic:340183”][quote author=Niall link=topic=436552.msg3207486#msg3207486 date=1273937033]

I don’t see any valid reason why drugs should be made legal, and how it would benefit anyone.

http://www.time.com/time/health/article/0,8599,1893946,00.html
[/quote]

I read that whole article, pretty interesting. “more Americans have used cocaine than Portuguese have used marijuana.” , but someone could also argue that Portugal has a population of 10 million people, opposed to the United State’s 300 million. I feel that if the United States tried this it wouldn’t work as well as it has in Portugal.[/quote]

Proportionally being the key word of that sentence.

Read full topic

item.title: Drugs. Legalization Vs Prohibiton
item.dc:creator: @Eh_Pretty_Easy Eh Pretty Easy
item.description:
@Eh_Pretty_Easy wrote:

I’m pretty sure that while cannabis is illegal in the Netherlands, one can possess small quantities of it without it actually being a criminal offence.

Growing up to half-a-dozen marijuana plants for home consumption is, effectively, legal. Commercial growing is, however, still illegal so the 'grow rooms' that supply the coffeeshops are still very secretive.

Read full topic

item.title: Drugs. Legalization Vs Prohibiton
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

R.I.P RSC:

I don’t think the shops are buying their drugs legally though.

Obviously I can’t speak first-hand, because I don’t live in the Netherlands or own a coffee shop, but if I remember correctly they are. There are a handful of places licensed to grow on a large scale in order to sell to licensed vendors, and the coffee shops MUST make sure they buy from those. The police crack down heavily on people who buy from unlicensed farmers in order to sell to the public.

OP should fact check this before quoting me though, because I don’t remember who told me.

Read full topic

item.title: Drugs. Legalization Vs Prohibiton
item.dc:creator: @Andrew Andrew
item.description:
@Andrew wrote:

Niall:

[quote author=Andrew link=topic=436552.msg3207422#msg3207422 date=1273933531]I don’t see any valid reason why drugs should be made legal, and how it would benefit anyone.

http://www.time.com/time/health/article/0,8599,1893946,00.html[/quote]

I read that whole article, pretty interesting. “more Americans have used cocaine than Portuguese have used marijuana.” , but someone could also argue that Portugal has a population of 10 million people, opposed to the United State’s 300 million. I feel that if the United States tried this it wouldn’t work as well as it has in Portugal.

Read full topic

item.title: Drugs. Legalization Vs Prohibiton
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

People who are willing to do drugs, will do them regardless of the law.

Prohibition just opens up many doors of danger to them. If drugs were legalized and regulated, violent drug gangs couldn’t exist and shady dealers couldn’t cut their product with potentially dangerous substances.

Prohibition doesn’t work. Just look at what happened with alcohol prohibition. Which leads me to ask, why should alcohol still be legal? It’s is an extremely dangerous drug, and yet it is one of the most commonly abused.

And if you think I deserve to be in prison for smoking pot, well then you are a joke and I can’t take you seriously. So fuck you
Our prisons are over crowded enough. Child molesters and murderers are getting released early, because our prisons are over crowded with non-violent drug offenders.

edit: Can’t be fucked to give a proper response. It’s been discussed so many times on this website and I feel like a broken record player. And read the chapters on http://www.drugwarfacts.org/cms/

Read full topic

item.title: Drugs. Legalization Vs Prohibiton

item.title: Drugs. Legalization Vs Prohibiton
item.dc:creator: @Greeny Greeny
item.description:
@Greeny wrote:

Weed should be legalised for over 9000 reasons. It wasn’t even made illegal because of it being a drug, it was more a quick fix to stop the hemp industry growing any larger.

I don’t even need to have this debate in regards to weed, just search the forum or the internet and mountains of information is available. However I’m fine with most/all other drugs remaining illegal.

I don’t buy the whole counter argument of legalised cannabis really fucking with the economy either, it’s going to create jobs in cannabis production, plus all the office jobs. Plus shit loads of jobs that become available when all the people who become stoners for the first time get fired. It would definitely be cheaper, probably more expensive than tobacco despite the fact weed can grow practically anywhere.

Read full topic
